title: 114_s2255
content: The Act may be cited as the "Stop Debt Collection Abuse Act of 2015". Section 803 of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act is amended to define the term 'debt' as any obligation of a consumer to pay money for personal, family, or household purposes, or to pay a loan, overpayment, fine, penalty, fee, or other money to a Federal agency that is at least 180 days past due. The term 'debt collector' is defined as any person who uses interstate commerce or mails to collect debts owed to another or purchased from another, or debts owed to a Federal agency. SEC. 3. DEBT COLLECTION PRACTICES FOR DEBT COLLECTORS HIRED BY GOVERNMENT AGENCIES. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act is amended to include section 812A, which outlines limitations on when federal agencies can transfer debts to debt collectors. A federal agency must wait at least 180 days before selling or transferring a debt to a collector and provide the consumer with three notifications before taking such action. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act now includes section 812A, which sets limits on federal agencies transferring debts to collectors. Notifications must be given to the consumer at least 30 days apart before any debt transfer occurs. SEC. 4. UNFAIR PRACTICES. Section 808 of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act is amended to restrict the collection of any amount unless authorized by the debt agreement or permitted by law, with specific conditions for amounts charged by debt collectors for Federal agencies. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act is amended to limit the amount collected by debt collectors to not exceed 10 percent of the total amount. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act is amended to limit the amount collected by debt collectors to not exceed 10 percent of the total amount. GAO will conduct a study and report on this matter. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on the use of debt collectors by State and local government agencies, focusing on powers, contracting processes, fees charged to debtors, consumer protection, and revenues received by debt collectors. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on the use of debt collectors by State and local government agencies, focusing on revenue sharing agreements, debt collection procedures, legal protections, and immunity given to debt collectors. A report will be submitted to Congress within 180 days of the enactment of this Act.
